35. Kingdon, (Mrs. F.)
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and will it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. J. King (signature)
Address: 2111 Yellow
Birthplace: Ontario

I was what I remember as a child in my mother's house.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1889
Where did you set up housekeeping? Valleyview, near Lethbridge
Where had you been living before that? Ontario
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3
How far was it to your nearest store? 3 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? .......................
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Sugar, flour, rice, apples, tea, coffee, butter, eggs, milk, cheese, bread, applesauce, jam, honey, syrup, vinegar, salt, pepper, spices.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? White
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 pounds
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ..............
How much did you use graham flour? ........................................
Whole wheat flour? ...............................................................
Was flour milled locally? Yes. How far away? 30 miles. What year? 1889
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 25 cents
What other grain products did you use? Beans, corn meal
Cornmeal? Yes. Whole wheat? No. Farine? No.
Other? Rolled oats, oatmeal
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? ...........................................................
Kingdon, Mrs. F.
Tantallon, 1952

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Porridge, toast, butter, tea, sugar, jam
Dinner: Stewed pork, potatoes, other vegetables, meat pudding, bread, butter
Supper: Warmed potatoes, eggs or coddled meat, fresh fruits or prunes, apple sauce (chilled), bread, butter

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? ...................... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Christmas pie, vegetable
Plum pudding (few prunes)
Bread, butter, bread & tea, butter

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level, living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No.
17. Give a special day to some (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the children. You can remember. Give the year and time. The number of the family or number.

Breakfast-Brunch: Toasted, eggs, bread, milk.

Supper: Warm potatoes, eggs or stew meat, applesauce (chilled).

18. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Indiana? Approve to agree at that time.

Christmas pie veg table

Pumpkin pudding (last chance)

Bread, butter, blood, a few crackers

19. Were you ever refused to almost starvation level living on one or two local products? Give details.

No.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

More variety
Get fresh meat every time
Get green vegetables in winter
All kinds of fresh fruits summer
and winter. Bury Baker bread
if we wish. Ice cream & Restaurant
meals if we wish.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We still depend a good deal
on home grown foods.

21. Please add other details from your experiences of buying groceries in India. Include items not mentioned above.

22. Please add other details from your experiences of traveling through India. Include items not mentioned above.

We went to many places, visited and dined at various restaurants. Our trip was very long and we had to carry heavy supplies of food. We found the people very friendly and welcoming. After three weeks, our trip ended with a good and peaceful journey.
